title-group.article-title: Insights on the antiradical capacity and mechanism of phytocannabinoids: H-abstraction and electron transfer processes in physiological media and the influence of the acid-base equilibrium

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Insights on the antiradical capacity and mechanism of phytocannabinoids: H-abstraction and electron transfer processes in physiological media and the influence of the acid-base equilibrium

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Houssem Boulebd

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Chemistry Department, Faculty of Exact Science, University of Constantine 1, Constantine , 25000, Algeria

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Phytocannabinoids
DFT calculations
Antioxidant activity
Kinetic study
A B S T R A C T

Phytocannabinoids are natural products primarily isolated from
Cannabis sativa
that exhibit the typical C21 terpenophenolic skeleton. This class of compounds has been shown to be effective in the treatment of various oxidation-related diseases, which has made their antioxidant properties the focus of increasing interest. In the present contribution, the primary antioxidant properties of eight representative phytocannabinoids have been systematically studied against a variety of biologically significant radical species using the density functional theory (DFT) method. The findings demonstrated that phytocannabinoids, in water at physiological pH, exhibit excellent radical scavenging capacity, mainly exerted by the single electron transfer (SET) process from the deprotonated state. In contrast, phytocannabinoids are moderate radical scavengers in non-polar environment via the formal hydrogen atom transfer (fHAT) process. Among the compounds examined, cannabichromene (CBC) and cannabifuran (CBF) had the greatest free radical scavenging capacity in water, surpassing even common antioxidants like BHT and Trolox. CBF is expected to have potent antiradical action toward peroxyl radicals, alkoxy radicals, and nitrogen dioxide in water at physiological pH. These results provide supporting evidence that phytocannabinoids may be useful in scavenging harmful free radicals in physiological environments.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: E-mail address: boulebd.houssem@umc.edu.dz.

sec.title: 2.1. Frontier molecular orbitals analysis
sec.p: Frontier molecular orbitals (FMOs) i.e., HOMO (highest occupied molecular orbital) and LUMO (lowest unoccupied molecular orbital) are useful tools for describing the scavenging activity of organic compounds. The distribution and energy of these orbitals can provide information about the sites of free radical attack as well as the overall ability of the molecule to act as an electron acceptor or donor. The FMOs of the phytocannabinoids studied are presented in Fig. 2 . From the obtained findings, it is clear that HOMOs and LUMOs are mainly located on the phenolic moieties of all compounds. This suggests that the OH groups of phytocannabinoids play a crucial role in determining their reactivity.

The energy of HOMO reflects the ability of the molecule to lose an electron. The results show that the HOMO energy of phytocannabinoids decreases in the following order CBE (6.20 eV) > CBC (6.98 eV) > CBN (6.99 eV) > CBND (7.05 eV) > CBF (7.07 eV) > TCBN (7.15 eV) > CBG (7.33 eV). This indicates that CBE, CBC, and CBN are the strongest electron donors, while TCBN and CBG are the weakest. Moreover, CBE (ΔE = 6.01 eV), CBC (ΔE = 6.74 eV), and CBN (ΔE = 6.74 eV) show a significantly small energy gap compared to that of CBG (7.10 eV), implying that these molecules are the most potent in terms of electron donating.

sec.title: 2.2. Chemical equilibria in aqueous media
sec.p: To investigate antiradical activity in water, it is necessary to understand acid-base equilibrium under physiological conditions (pH = 7.4). Since experimental data on phytocannabinoids are lacking, the relative pKa values were calculated using a procedure described in the literature (Rebollar-Zepeda et al., 2011). The computed values are shown in Fig. 3 , and Fig. S2 depicts the mole fraction as a function of the pH of the neutral and anionic species. The molar fractions have been calculated using the following equations:
10 pKa
%Phyto O – = ) × 100

As per Fig. 3 , it can be seen that the neutral form is prevalent at physiological pH (7.4), with ratios ranging from 99.01% to 99.97% ( Table S2 ). The anionic form, on the other hand, is present in low concentrations ranging from 0.02% to 0.99% ( Table S2 ). The fHAT and RAF mechanisms should be unaffected by this minimum proportion, but it may be critical for the SET process. As a result, the anionic form is investigated in this study for the SET mechanism in water, whereas only the neutral form is investigated for fHAT and RAF mechanisms.

sec.title: 2.3. Thermodynamic behavior of antiradical mechanisms
sec.p: Antioxidants react with free radicals to produce much less reactive species in which the free electron is distributed over the entire molecule and not localized on a single atom. This process can take place according to several mechanisms involving hydrogen transfer (fHAT), electron transfer (SET) or by a non-redox path (RAF) according to the following equations:
Antiox H + R • → Antiox • + RH (fHAT)
Antiox + R • → Antiox +• + R (SET)
Antiox + R • → [Antiox R] • (RAF)

fHAT and RAF involve uncharged species; thus, their feasibility is possible under both polar and lipid conditions. On the other hand, SET involves the transfer of electrons from an anionic or a neutral species leading to a neutral or a cationic radical as follows:
Antiox OH + R • → [Antiox OH] +• + R (SET1)
Antiox O + R • → Antiox O ⋅ + R (SET2)

Phytocannabinoids ( Fig. 1 ) have several potential sites for free radial attack. According to the fHAT mechanism, the phenolic OH groups are the most suitable sites for donating their hydrogen atoms; however, studies on antioxidants have shown that some benzylic hydrogen atoms may also be involved in the hydrogen transfer process. Furthermore, we previously demonstrated that cannabidiolic acid (CBDA) interacts with HOO • in lipid environments via a benzylic group rather than a phenolic OH group (
). Thus, in addition to the phenolic OH groups, all potential CH groups were examined in this study. In terms of the RAF mechanism, it is known that the attack of HOO • on the aromatic nucleus is energetically unfavorable since it destroys aromaticity. Only attacks on non-phenolic double bonds are possible. This was also taken into consideration in this study.

Fig. 4 shows the computed Gibbs free energies of the reaction of phytocannabinoids with HOO • following fHAT, RAF, and SET mechanisms in physiological media. As can be seen, in both environments, the phenolic OH groups of all phytocannabinoids show low ΔG values for the fHAT mechanism ranging from 3.1 to 1.9 kcal/mol. This implies that this process is thermodynamically favorable for these OH groups. Similarly, benzylic CH groups, including 3 CH and 12 CH of TCBN and CBG respectively, also showed low ΔG values of 9.9 to 1.2 kcal/mol, reflecting the feasibility of fHAT for these two groups as well. Considering the RAF mechanism, it appears that the reactions at positions C4, C19, C20, and (C17, C18) of CBC, CBND, CBE, and CBG, respectively are exergonic or almost isergonic. Therefore, RAF is a thermodynamically possible mechanism for some phytocannabinoids. Finally, the ΔG values of the SET mechanism are slightly endergonic (0.5 to 4.3 kcal/mol) and indicate that SET is also possible in water.

sec.title: 2.4. Kinetic study under physiological conditions
sec.p: In the first step, the kinetic study of the reaction of phytocannabinoids with HOO • was performed in the gas phase for all the thermodynamically conceivable pathways and the results obtained are reported in Table S2 . Only, the fHAT and RAF mechanisms were considered since they are relatively slightly dependent on the environments. As we can see, the calculated branching ratios show that fHAT is the dominant process for all phytocannabinoids, while RAF has no contribution to the overall rate constant (Γ = 0%). The 3 CH group of the TCBN has a rate constant of 1.08 × 104 M 1 s 1 which contributes 28% to the k overall . This implies that this CH group may play a role in the primary antioxidant activity of TCBN. On the other hand, that of CBG (12 CH ) has no contribution to the k overall with a rate constant of 2.53 × 10 1 M 1 s 1 (Γ = 0%).

Based on this preliminary assessment in the gas phase, the antiradical activity in the lipid-like environment was modeled following the fHAT mechanism at the phenolic OH groups and the active CH groups. On the other hand, the SET mechanism from the anionic state was also considered in water. The overall rate constants ( k overall ) were calculated as follows:
In the lipid-like environment
k overall = k app(fHAT OH) + k app (fHAT CH )
In water
k overall = k f (fHAT OH) + k f (fHAT CH ) + k f (SET2)
a The nuclear reorganization energy (λ).
b Mole fraction.
c K = f . k .
f app

To get a more reliable estimation of the antiradical potency of phytocannabinoids, the predicted rate constant of CBF, as the most active derivative in polar physiological environments, was compared to the experimental value of the reference antioxidant Trolox. The molar fraction of the HOO • radical at physiological pH (0.00251), however, must be included in the koverall of CBF to obtain a reliable result as follows: ) k fHAT (CBF) = k appfHAT 9.90 × 10 2 × fCBF(0.9901) × fHOO(0.00251)
k overall = k f (fHAT) + k f (SET2) = 1.32 × 10 4 M 1 s 1

As we can see, the value obtained for CBF (1.32 × 10 4 M 1 s 1 ) is comparable to the experimental value of Trolox (1.70 × 104 M 1 s 1 ) (
), indicating that CBF is a potent scavenger of HOO • in polar physiological environments.

In light of these findings, it can be seen that CBF and CBC are the most effective HOO • scavengers in both environments while being as effective as reference antioxidants Trolox and BHT. This leads us to conclude that CBF and CBC are promising HOO • scavengers in physiological media.
2.5. Scavenging potential toward typical free radicals in water

sec.title: 3. Conclusion
sec.p: The radical scavenging ability of phytocannabinoids has been systematically assessed using both thermodynamic and kinetic calculations under physiological conditions. In light of these computations, it can be concluded that the antiradical capacity of phytocannabinoids depends on the environment and the structure of the molecule. In the lipid-like environment, phytocannabinoids are relatively moderate to good HOO • scavengers, reacting mainly according to the fHAT mechanism. However, in water at physiological pH, the antiradical properties of phytocannabinoids are substantially better and mainly defined by the SET mechanism from the anionic state, which is in good agreement with the available experimental data. CBN, CBC, and CBF were identified as the most promising molecules in water for scavenging HOO • radical with overall rate constants higher than that of reference compounds Trolox and BHT. Furthermore, CBF exhibited excellent free radical scavenging activity against peroxyl radicals, methoxy radicals, and nitrogen dioxide. These findings may shed new light on how phytocannabinoids exert their antiradical action and inspire the development of novel potential derivatives.
